docs.lead_paragraph: The re-election of the president's brother in Florida was the test Democrats chose to weaken George W. Bush's political clout. Bill Clinton and Al Gore stumped against Jeb Bush; Clinton's Democratic National Committee boss poured in millions. The Bush brothers greeted the personal challenge with enthusiasm. Jeb Bush won big; George W. won even bigger. In Florida and all across the country, the president laid his high ratings on the line to give national meaning to local elections. Had his party in the White House suffered the usual midterm losses in Congress and statehouses, Democrats would have said he had been repudiated. The opposite happened; his gutsy gamble paid off, and Bush's 2000 victory was resoundingly validated.
docs.abstract: William Safire Op-Ed column says Gov Jeb Bush won big and Pres George W Bush won even bigger as, in Florida and across country, he laid his high public opinion ratings on line to give national meaning to local elections; says Republicans, with new political dominance, have no excuse for failing to deliver on range of issues; says opposition must conceive and articulate contrary views and press is charged more than ever to investigate and expose (M)
docs.snippet: The re-election of the president's brother in Florida was the test Democrats chose to weaken George W. Bush's political clout. Bill Clinton and Al Gore stumped against Jeb Bush; Clinton's Democratic National Committee boss poured in millions. The...

docs.lead_paragraph: Waking to a new power configuration in Washington yesterday, business leaders began to revise their wish lists for action on contentious issues like taxes, health care costs, personal-injury lawsuits and the ability of government employees to strike. ''This historic election sets the stage for aggressive action'' on a pro-business agenda, said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. He listed the association's top goals as expanded tax cuts, a new law governing terrorism insurance, a prescription drug policy for the elderly and a resolution of asbestos-related lawsuits that have hurt the stock prices of manufacturers and prompted numerous companies to seek protection in bankruptcy court.

headline.main: Corporations Revise Wish Lists; Republican Victory Sets Stage for Pro-Business Agenda

docs.abstract: Corporations are revising wish lists as Republican Party captures majorities in both houses of Congress in midterm elections sets stage for pro-business agenda; issues facing Washington include brand-name drugs, fuel-economy standards, energy and taxes; many executives and business leaders stress that Republicans' majorities are slender and that they are not sure American business will achieve its most important goals; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Waking to a new power configuration in Washington yesterday, business leaders began to revise their wish lists for action on contentious issues like taxes, health care costs, personal-injury lawsuits and the ability of government employees to strike....

docs.lead_paragraph: The Principal Financial Group, a leading seller of 401(k) retirement plans, posted a third-quarter loss set off by $201 million of costs for closing the BT Financial Group, its Australian money management unit. The insurer lost $158.4 million, or 45 cents a share, compared with net income of $115.8 million, or 32 cents a share, in the third quarter of 2001. Excluding investment losses of $146.9 million and the BT Financial expense, profit rose 20 percent, to $202.5 million, from the 2001 period, Principal said.
docs.abstract: Principal Financial Group reports $158.4 million third-quarter loss, including expenses and investment losses, or 45 cents a share; operating profit rises to 58 cents a share from 47 cents year earlier (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators are planning a comprehensive review of Medicare reimbursements to Tenet Healthcare, one of the nation's largest chains of for-profit hospitals, the company said yesterday. The review will focus on payments for cases that are unusually costly and therefore qualify for special reimbursement under Medicare rules. The Department of Health and Human Services contacted Tenet about performing an audit to make sure the payments were appropriate, Tenet said, and the agency will examine how the payments were calculated.

headline.main: Tenet Faces Agency Audit Of Payments For Medicare

docs.abstract: Department of Health and Human Services plans to conduct comprehensive review of Medicare reimbursements to Tenet Healthcare, focusing on payments for cases that are unusually costly and therefore qualify for special reimbursement; company expresses confidence that federal audit will find its hospitals obey all rules; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Education advocates, lottery promoters and animal welfare groups were among the big winners in ballot initiatives taken up by voters on Tuesday, while groups seeking to change drug policy and health care fared poorly. In Florida and California, voters approved sweeping measures to reduce class size and expand after-school programs, respectively, but did not provide financing for them.

headline.main: School and Animal Welfare Measures Prove Popular, but Health Care Falters

docs.abstract: Fate of ballot initiatives on various issues across country summarized; Florida and California voters approve sweeping measures to reduce class size and expand after-school programs, albeit without funding; Californians approve $13-billion school construction bond measure, but initiative by actor Arnold Schwarzenegger claims more than $400 million of education budget for tutoring and enrichment programs; animal rights measures succeed in several states; North Dakota and Tennessee voters clear way for state lotteries; advocates of drug policy reform are rebuffed, Nevadans rejecting legalization of small amounts of marijuana; Oregonians reject universal health care plan and also labeling of food products with genetically-altered ingredients (M)
docs.snippet: Education advocates, lottery promoters and animal welfare groups were among the big winners in ballot initiatives taken up by voters on Tuesday, while groups seeking to change drug policy and health care fared poorly.    In Florida and California,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans scored upset victories last night in governor's races in Maryland, Massachusetts and Georgia, where an obscure former state senator named Sonny Perdue became the first Republican elected governor since Reconstruction. On a grim night for Democrats nationally, the party's candidates won the governor's offices in Illinois, Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin, throwing four populous potential roadblocks in the way of President Bush's drive to re-election in 2004.

headline.main: G.O.P. May Retain Its Lead in Statehouses

docs.abstract: Republicans score upset victories in governor's races in Maryland, Massachusetts and Georgia; Democrats win in Illinois, Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin, throwing four populous potential roadblocks in way of Pres Bush's re-election, but fail to unseat his brother Jeb in Florida or Rick Perry, Bush's successor as governor of Texas; photo of Rod Blagojevich of Illinois; Republicans do well in Northeast, easily winning re-election in New York and Connecticut and picking up New Hampshire office that Jeanne Shaheen gave up in unsuccessful bid for Senate; Democrat Jim Hodges is ousted by Mark Sanford in South Carolina; little-known Republican Sonny Perdue stuns Georgia Gov Roy Barnes; Mitt Romney wins in Mass and Robert L Ehrlich Jr is first Republican governor of Maryland in 36 years; Republicans also win in Nebraska, Ohio, Colorado, Rhode Island, Nevada, Idaho, South Dakota and Arkansas and lead in Vermont; Democrats win in Republican strongholds Kansas, Arizona, New Mexico and Oklahoma, as well as in Maine and Iowa (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Donald S. MacNaughton, an insurance and health care executive who, from the late 1960's to the mid-1980's, ran two of the nation's biggest companies -- first the Prudential Insurance Company of America and then the Hospital Corporation of America -- died on Sunday in a hospital in Greenwich, Conn. He was 85 and maintained residences in Greenwich and Chatham, Mass. The cause was a cerebral hemorrhage, said Joe Vecchione, a retired vice president of Prudential.

headline.main: Donald MacNaughton, 85, Ex-Chief of Prudential Financial

docs.abstract: Donald S MacNaughton, former chief of Prudential Financial, dies at age 85; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Voters in 40 states weighed in on a wide array of citizen-backed ballot initiatives and referendums that sought fundamental changes in health care, drug policy, school programs and transportation. In Oregon, a plan to create a single statewide health plan for all residents appeared to be headed for resounding defeat. The proposal would have replaced almost all public and private health care programs and individual health insurance, at a cost to state taxpayers of $1.7 billion in the first year.

headline.main: Candidates Share Space With Issues Like Health Care and Marijuana Laws

docs.abstract: Voters in forty states cast ballots on wide array of initiatives and referendums; Oregon voters apparently defeat single health-care plan and labeling of genetically-altered foods; Nevada voters turn down marijuana legalization; Floridians approve ban on smoking in indoor workplaces and class size limitations; Mass voters move to abolish bilingual education (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki, a pragmatic Republican who ran a campaign intended to appeal as much to liberals as to conservatives, was elected to a third term yesterday with a solid majority, ending the quest of the Democratic challenger, H. Carl McCall, to become the state's first black governor. In other New York races, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer obliterated his Republican opponent, Dora Irizarry, to win a second term, firmly establishing himself as one of the brightest young stars in the state Democratic Party and a possible candidate for governor.

headline.main: Pataki Coasts to a 3rd Term; McCall Is a Distant Second

docs.abstract: Gov George E Pataki, pragmatic Republican, is elected to third term in New York with solid majority over H Carl McCall; photos; Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer obliterates Dora Irizarry, firmly establishing himself as rising Democratic star and potential gubernatorial candidate; Comptroller Alan G Hevesi squeaks by Republican John J Faso; Frank R Lautenberg is elected once again to Senate from New Jersey; Conn Gov John G Rowland wins easily; Pataki is only third Republican, with Thomas E Dewey and Nelson A Rockefeller, to win more than two terms in New York; McCall, who failed to raise enough money, did not hold onto Democratic base and made key campaign errors, comes close to record loss for Democrat; Pataki gets 50 percent of vote to 33 percent for McCall and 14 percent for Independence Party nominee Tom Golisano, with 98 percent of districts reporting; county-by-county tally; maps; Liberal Party fails to get 50,000 votes needed to automatically remain on ballot (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: SHPS, a closely held provider of human resources and health services, agreed yesterday to buy EBenX for $4.85 a share, or about $98 million in cash. Shares of EBenX, which helps companies manage employee health benefits, more than doubled, to close at $4.70. The combined company, to be called SHPS, will be based in Louisville, Ky., where SHPS is based. The transaction is expected to close in the first quarter. Separately, EBenX, based in Minneapolis, said its third-quarter net loss narrowed to $585,000, or 3 cents a share, from $9.31 million, or 47 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose 52 percent, to $13.8 million from $9.1 million.

headline.main: SHPS, A HEALTH CARE COMPANY, PLANS TO ACQUIRE EBENX

docs.abstract: SHPS, closely held provider of human resources and health services, agrees to buy EBenX, employee health benefits management firm, for about $98 million cash, or $4.85 a share (S)
